skill.name: internal-comms
skill.description: A set of resources to help me write all kinds of internal communications, using the formats that my company likes to use. Claude should use this skill whenever asked to write some sort of internal communications (status reports, leadership updates, 3P updates, company newsletters, FAQs, incident reports, project updates, etc.).

content.value_statement: Streamline your internal company communications with AI-powered templates and guidelines for 3P updates, newsletters, FAQs, and more.
actual_capabilities: Write structured 3P (Progress, Plans, Problems) updates for teams
Draft comprehensive company-wide newsletters with proper formatting
Create FAQ documents by identifying common questions and providing answers
Generate status reports, leadership updates, and project communications
Apply consistent formatting and tone across all communication types
Integrate with workplace tools (Slack, Email, Google Drive, Calendar) when available
Customize communications based on audience size and organizational context
limitations: Requires user input or tool access for company-specific information
Cannot access company systems without proper integrations
Template-based approach may need customization for unique company cultures
Effectiveness depends on quality of source information provided

use_cases.title: Weekly Team Updates
use_cases.description: Generate concise 3P updates summarizing your team's progress, upcoming plans, and current blockers in a format executives can read in under 60 seconds
use_cases.target_user: Team leads, managers, and project coordinators

use_cases.title: Company Newsletter
use_cases.description: Compile and format a comprehensive company-wide newsletter highlighting major announcements, achievements, and updates across all departments
use_cases.target_user: Internal communications teams, executive assistants, HR departments

use_cases.title: FAQ Documentation
use_cases.description: Identify recurring questions across your organization and create clear, authoritative answers to reduce confusion and information silos
use_cases.target_user: HR teams, operations managers, internal communications specialists

use_cases.title: Leadership Communications
use_cases.description: Draft professional internal announcements, incident reports, or strategic updates with appropriate tone and structure

prompt_templates.title: Weekly 3P Update
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a 3P update for the [team name] covering [date range]. Our progress includes [accomplishments], our plans are [upcoming work], and our problems are [blockers].
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to send a quick status update to leadership about your team's weekly activities

prompt_templates.title: Monthly Newsletter
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a company newsletter for [month] covering our major announcements, product launches, new hires, and team achievements.
prompt_templates.scenario: When compiling a monthly digest of company-wide news and updates

prompt_templates.title: FAQ Document
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate an FAQ document answering common questions about [topic/initiative] based on questions from [Slack/email/meetings].
prompt_templates.scenario: When you notice recurring questions about a new policy, product, or initiative

prompt_templates.title: General Internal Communication
prompt_templates.prompt: Write an internal communication to [audience] about [topic] with a [formal/casual/urgent] tone.
prompt_templates.scenario: For any internal communication that doesn't fit standard formats

best_practices: Confirm team name and time period before writing 3P updates
Use data and metrics where possible to make communications concrete
Keep 3P updates to 30-60 seconds reading time (1-3 sentences per section)
Link to relevant documents, Slack threads, or emails for context
Match the company's existing communication style and tone
Focus on company-wide impact for newsletters, not team-specific details
Base FAQ answers on official communications when available
Use the 'we' tense for company newsletters to maintain collective voice
anti_patterns: Writing 3P updates that are too detailed or lengthy for executive consumption
Including team-specific minutiae in company-wide newsletters
Creating FAQs without linking to authoritative sources
Using inconsistent formatting that deviates from provided templates
Making assumptions about company information without confirming with user
Writing in overly formal or prose-heavy style when matter-of-fact tone is needed

faq.question: What are 3P updates?
faq.answer: 3P stands for Progress, Plans, Problems. They're succinct weekly team summaries designed for executives to read in 30-60 seconds, covering what was accomplished, what's coming next, and what's blocking the team.

faq.question: Can this skill access my company's Slack or Google Drive?
faq.answer: The skill provides instructions for using those tools if available through integrations, but you'll need to provide the information directly or ensure Claude has appropriate tool access configured.

faq.question: How do I customize the format for my company?
faq.answer: The templates provide standard formats, but you can specify custom formatting requirements, tone preferences, or company-specific style guidelines when making requests.

faq.question: What's the difference between a 3P update and a newsletter?
faq.answer: 3P updates are brief weekly team summaries for leadership. Newsletters are comprehensive company-wide digests (20-25 bullets) covering announcements, achievements, and updates across all departments.

faq.question: Can this help with incident communications or crisis updates?
faq.answer: Yes, the general-comms template can be used for incident reports and urgent communications. Specify the audience, purpose, and desired tone when requesting.
